v_91: We don't believe that a standardized RE reference model provides value to us
v_103: Again: We think, standardized RE models are the wrong way
v_195: The optimal interface between Product Owner and team is negotiated during the course of the project between the two
v_207: No standard; Project specific negotiations are monitored via retrospectives by both team and PO
v_112: Continuous improvement is core of an agile approach to work
v_214: Retrospectives and monthly Company wide Open Space events
v_216: We don't improve to reach compliane to any internal or external standard (unless the domain enforces us, i.e. medical) but to optimize quality and service level for the customer. We don't believe that a standard is helpful in this task
v_223: Collaborative reflection during retrospectives and using whatever tol is appropriate to improve us
v_224: Customer Satisfaction (e.g. A/B tests, NPS, etc.)
v_391: Not really a problem, but a condition of the environment: The business world changes faster than most projects run
v_392: Requirements emerge and change priority once the system is deployed. Again, this is no problem but the environment. It becomes a problem if you're not prepared to deal with it
v_393: Actually this is less a problem of the stakeholders but of insufficient understanding. Again it only becomes a problem if you ignore it
v_394: Most unfunctional requirements are too complex to be caged into simple numbers. Understanding the real need of the users/customers is crucial here
v_395: A classical problem if you split RE and implementation. Usually non-existent if you work in close contact and using time-boxing and if the business experts get transparency about the real cost of their reqs early
v_266: My problem with this survey was that it was based upon the idea that a standardized and separated req process actually is a good idea. If you work according to agile ideas, this usually is not the case (unless the domain enforces tracebility). So I wasn't able to provide meaningful answers to many of the question
